data.title: The Eavesdropper Goes to Woody Allen’s New Movie
data.meta_description: Woody Allen’s new movie ‘Coup de Chance’ played at only one Manhattan theater this week. The Eavesdropper sat in, listening to the director’s super fans.
data.text:
Woody Allen’s 50th film, Coup de Chance, came out on Friday. Not that you would know. There were no screenings last weekend in Allen’s native Brooklyn. In Manhattan, the movie played at a single theater at Quad Cinema, on West 13th, where it showed on a screen so small that the size elicited much discussion. The crowd included couples on dates, the kind of retirees and families who see everything, groups of film buffs, and many French speakers. (Which makes sense: The 96-minute romp was filmed in Paris with a French cast.) The Eavesdropper showed up early, lingered in the lobby, and left with a group of film boys in windbreakers who gave their critiques en route to the West 4th Street station.

It’s a stupid debate, or what I would say, talking about it as praxism literally, rather than talking about certain elements is meaningless. It’s not like we banned Trump.

Yeah, it’s not confusing if you think about it as Is this part of the pattern of fascism — historical fascism?

There’s actually a lot of people here.

[Whispers] I love Woody Allen.

The less I know about his personal life the better.

I’m kind of surprised that they’re doing this. Did you see the last one?

Oh it’s so small.

It’s cute cute, cute, cute.

Oui! Teeny tiny.

Oui ça va?

Ça va bien.

It’s such a small theater. It’s like someone’s private showing.

Should we do three here?

Want the middle?

You want the middle? Are you ready for middling?

That was so good. Oh my God.

Ha! I loved it.

I felt like I was watching something underwater: all the weird angles?Seriously, what was going on? That was crazy.

The characters are so ugly, I get annoyed at how ugly they are.

Will you hold my bag a minute?

Excellent! It was excellent!

I’m not surprised.

That was good. I’m trying to remember the last Woody Allen I saw—

So I remember I liked the one about the tennis in London.

I liked that one.

I watched the tennis one more than once.

I liked her, but I liked the other women in the movie better: the wife.

So cheesy I know, but it works.

The part that felt really Woody Allen was the jazz, that was the throughline.

The whole theme of the movie was the luck of the draw, and boy oh boy did she luck out.

And that one last visit to that adorable apartment?

Oh my God, wasn’t it adorable?

That was better than the last one.

That was pretty good, honestly.

Yeah, it was better than I expected.

I don’t know how seriously to take the writer—

You don’t think he’s a stand-in for Woody Allen?

I thought at the beginning, we’re supposed to take the melodrama seriously.

That’s every Woody Allen movie.

But there’s a layer of mocking-ness in other Woody Allens?

But this character isn’t like — I just mean if you watch Radio Days or Purple Rose of Cairo, there’s a writer who’s too sincere, without that part of his performance of it.

But he’s serious about it, he just can’t help but be unserious in the role.

He’s self-mocking.

He is.

He is.

It’s serious beyond the layer of mocking irony.

His things about love are very serious?

I think the writer was supposed to be serious but the way he was killed, and the lack of sentiment around it; it was funny.

Why did it look like a Terrence Malick movie for half the time? The camera would like, swoop?

He’s relinquished some clear control.

There’s no romance in making movies anymore. It’s true.

I don’t know why he didn’t make his getting canceled into a bit?

It is! It’s all about a writer who’s wrongfully killed for being with the wrong woman: Is it not exactly this? It’s these evil censors who don’t believe in luck who need to be killed! It’s a real roman à clef!

Laughs

That was pretty good though. They tied things together quite nicely.

The way the writer was killed was so anticlimactic, so unsentimental.

I think it’s a very brittle movie. Everything is played for laughs.

It’s very similar to Match Point, or Crimes and Misdemeanors.

Yes.

Crimes and Misdemeanors is way more a comedy. It had all these interludes of the professor, We are alone on the planet …

[Laughs.]

The constant refrain of the Herbie Hancock song was making me laugh so hard.

What’s the best train for us?

The BD.

Oh the B stops running at 9:30.

[Pause]

Would you do that to X’s lover? Would you hire someone to do a cowardly way to kill him?

No!

Or it’s a question of character: Would you be more willing to kill someone, or to die?

I’d prefer to kill than to die.

They’re extending it! Probably a week.
